author: Lakita  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Nov 11, 2008 6:06 am Gender: Female
title: Can I be taller than I already am? 4'8
content: Hello, I'm 4'8 at 18. My mom's 4'11 and dad's 5'8. I am of Hawaiian/Filipino decent. Is there anything that can help me grow? I drink my milk everyday, I eat fairly well. I'm honestly tired of wearing heels, using stools and asking people for help to reach something at stores...it makes me feel like I can't do anything for myself (height wise) All I want is a few inches be like my mothers height..anything! Thanks for your guys'  help.
posted_time: Post  by Lakita » Tue Nov 11, 2008 6:15 am

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Can I be taller than I already am? 4'8
content: Hi Lakita,  The bones can continue to significant growth only until the growth plates close.  After the growth plates have closed, the chances of significant height increase are minimal.  For girls, by age 18 the growth plates are likely closed up so, unfortunately, I suspect you won't gain a lot more height.  You may gain another 1/2 inch or so but probably not much more.   To predict adult height, the mother and father's height can be averaged together with a correction factor for the child being a boy or girl (adding 5 inches to mom's height for boys, subtracting 5 inches from dad's height for girls then dividing the sum of the two heights by 2).  For you, your mid-parental height would be  5' 1".  This is the estimate of the 50'th percentile for your predicted height.  If you are now 4' 8" you are still within the range of expected heights.  The bad news is that there is very little that you can do (or could have done) about your ultimate height.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Chan Lowe » Thu Oct 27, 2011 12:58 am

Could the pills triggered false results? What steps should I take from here? Should I discontinue taking appetite suppressents as well?
posted_time: Post  by lb2005 » Fri May 15, 2009 1:08 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: High t4 count and birth control
content: Hello Lb2005,  Do you know your TSH level?  TSH is the hormone that stimulates the production of T4.  If it is normal then I would not worry about the T4 being a little high.  If it is low, this would be a sign of a hyperthyroid state that may need treatment.    If the TSH isn't normal you may want to see an endocrinologist or your primary care doctor for further testing to see why it is abnormal and if treatment is necessary.  Best wishes.

author: theleatherwing  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Aug 03, 2010 9:08 pm Gender: Male
title: pregnancy sans pituitary gland?
content: here's the situation- my girlfriend had a brain tumor about a year ago, and when they removed it, they also took her pituitary gland out. she has to take pills every day and whatnot to supply her with hormones and they told her that she couldn't have a kid without major fertility treatments. one of the pills she takes every day is the birth control pill, and she asked her endocrinologist right before we had sex if she could get pregnant and the doctor said it was impossible, so we opted out of protection.  but now she's five days late on her period. could she possibly be pregnant?  sorry if i should have posted this on a different forum.  --a scared teenager
posted_time: Post  by theleatherwing » Tue Aug 03, 2010 9:17 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: pregnancy sans pituitary gland?
content: Hello Theleatherwing,  This is a little bit of a difficult question to answer.  If the pituitary gland was completely removed then pregnancy is essentially impossible since the pituitary gland makes FSH and LH, which control the development and release of eggs and the menstrual cycle, basically.  If, by chance, enough of the pituitary gland was left that LH and FSH are still being made pregnancy is possible; however, if this were the case, one would expect the menstrual cycle to continue to be normal without the need for birth control pills.  (I am assuming she was started on the birth control to replace her natural hormonal cycles that are now not being stimulated by LH and FSH.)  The odds lean in favor of pregnancy being highly unlikely.  I suspect her cycle will start soon but if not, I would recommend she take a pregnancy test just to be sure.    Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Late Bloomer and Puberty Problems
content: Hello Mfshake,  Some men do enter puberty later than others.  Often the full course can take 2-4 years or so.  Occasionally, men will not "complete" puberty.  By this, I don't mean the body doesn't complete puberty but that the body may simply stop developing when the man thinks it should continue.  The range of normal is large.    If you are concerned I would recommend you talk with your doctor about the issue.  If needed, you can be referred to an endocrinologist to evaluate this issue further.  Best wishes.

author: Jess4mela  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Aug 03, 2010 4:29 pm Gender: Female
title: Androgen or Estrogen Dominant?
content: I stopped using Ortho Evra, the patch, over a year ago. Since then I have gained 25lbs without any changes to diet and exercise. A few months back I started dieting and exercising more than my usual 3 days a week. I have also used diet pills. With all of the changes I managed to lose 1 pound. After doing research I believe that this has something to do with a possible hormone imbalance. With Ortho Evra having such an extremely high amount of estrogen in it, is it likely that my body is lacking estrogen? Is it more likely that I have become androgen dominant or estrogen dominant? Since being off birth control I have also developed painful acne and I have had a few ovarian cysts.
posted_time: Post  by Jess4mela » Tue Aug 03, 2010 4:49 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Androgen or Estrogen Dominant?
content: Hello Jess4mela,  It is actually common for women to gain weight after stopping hormonal birth control.  Hormonal control is fairly complex in the body and the sex hormones influence many different systems.  Often what we see is that women will have some some rebound type symptoms after stopping birth control.  This does not necessarily mean that you have become androgen dominant.  It likely simply means your seeing more fluctuation in hormone levels that is causing your symptoms.  When on the patch, your hormone levels become very consistent and level things out.  From the information you've provided it sounds like your body is working properly.  Women do use hormonal contraception to treat the symptoms you are describing and some women choose to continue on them simply for purposes of control of acne or cysts.  Talking with your doctor can help you decide how best to proceed.  Best wishes.

content: When I was on 150mcg levoxyl I tested too low. Now that I've been on 175mcg for over a year it's too high. My P.C. and Endocrinologist say to take 150 and 175mcg on alternate days to achieve a level in between. Does this make sense and if so how? Or, should I be taking a 150mcg and 1/2 a 25mcg to put me at 162.5mcg?                                                                  Thankyou,                                                                            Bobster
posted_time: Post  by mastiff » Mon Aug 09, 2010 6:16 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Levoxyl 150mcg too low/175mcg too high
content: Hi Bobster,  Alternating days of your dose is a very reasonable way to get a mid-level dose of thyroid hormone.  The half-life of the drug is long enough that this possible to do.  Cutting a tablet to make a 162.5 dose would essentially do the same thing but then you have to deal with cutting tablets, which may or may not be easy depending on the tablet.  If you do opt for cutting the tablet, be sure your doctor is aware of this and approves it.  Some pills cannot be cut or it messes up their timed release.    Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Too high Levothyroxine causing problems?
content: Hello Andraded,  I would recommend you follow up with your doctor.  You likely need to have your thyroid levels tested.  125 mcg's is a respectable dose but not necessarily high.  The important thing is to match what the body needs.  This is done by testing a hormone called thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).  If the TSH is in the normal range, the dose is correct regardless of how high or low the dose is.    Thyroid medication dose needs can change over time and regular testing of TSH is important.  If you are getting too much or too little you can definitely feel miserable since thyroid hormone impacts nearly every system in the body.  If you do not have insurance there are often clinics in town that will see patients on a no fee or sliding fee scale depending on income and ability to pay.  Your local health department can help you find these clinics.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: hypothyroid convert in hyper thyroid due to medication
content: Hello Rajeshrisoni,  TSH is thyroid stimulating hormone.  It is made by the pituitary gland to stimulate the thyroid gland to make the thyroid hormones T3 and T4.  T4 is more stable and is generally measures to look for function.  Because TSH is a stimulating hormone, it will react in the opposite direction of the body state (i.e. if the body is low on thyroid hormone, the TSH goes up, if the body is high on thyroid hormone the TSH goes down).  TSH will continue to respond to the thyroid hormone taken by mouth as well, so TSH is used to titrate the oral medication.  If the TSH goes high, the medication needs increased.  If TSH goes low, the medication needs decreased.    There is one piece of information that is missing to help me in interpreting your labs-the normal values for your lab.  A common normal range for TSH is 0.4-4; however, this varies from lab to lab.  So, if a TSH of 0.06 is normal for your lab then your dose is appropriate.  If it is low, you may need to decrease the dose a bit.  Do not do this without the advice and direction of your doctor.  The thyroid regulates nearly every system in the body so care must be taken when adjusting the medicine.  Your doctor may feel that even though the TSH may be a little low, if everything is working right he may want you to stay on the dose you are on.    Regular checks of TSH are necessary as the body's need for amounts varies from time to time so a stable dose for years may need to be adjusted at some point.  A common evaluation time is 3-6 months (sometimes longer in certain situations).  Your doctor will help you.  Regarding  breastfeeding, your baby's thyroid should be regulating his levels.  Taking thyroid medicine while breastfeeding is safe and is important to help keep mom healthy and able to care for baby.  Best wishes.

author: phislth1  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Tue Aug 10, 2010 9:35 pm Gender: Female
title: Can you take the ACTH Stim test while on Cortisone Acetate
content: I was seeing a physicians assistant for a year.  She who was treating me for hypothyroidism.  I wasn't tolerating the westhroid she prescribed.  She had a saliva test ran and told me I had adrenal insuffiency.  I decided to seek the opinion of an endocrinologist.    After seeing my labs from the physicans assistant, he started me on 40mg of cortisone acetate.  Drew blood and told me to return in a week.  When I returned he ran the ACTH Stim test.  The results of the test showed I didn't stimulate any.  The blood drawn prior to the injection showed 18 and my 30 minute draw after the injection was 19, the hour blood draw was 18.  Based on this, my endo said I had adrenal failure.    I was concerned about the accuracy of the test since I was taking the Cortisone Acetate for a week prior to the test.  I asked my endo and he said the first blood he took would serve as a baseline and I should still "stimulate" after the injection.  My friends theory was that my body had shut down production of cortisol since I was on the CA making the results inaccurate.   Is a week on CA long enough to shut down my natural production of cortisol?  Does CA interfer with the ACTH test?     Do I need to wean off the CA and retest?   Thank you for your time.
posted_time: Post  by phislth1 » Tue Aug 10, 2010 10:10 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Can you take the ACTH Stim test while on Cortisone Acetate
content: Hello Phislth1,  This is a tricky question.  Cortisone and cortisol (the body hormone made by the adrenal glands) are exactly the same compound and the cortisone taken by mouth will be picked up by the lab test. Your endocrinologist is correct that the adrenal glands should still be stimulated by ACTH; however, this response can be blunted by being on the cortisone itself.  Taking exogenous (not made by the body) cortisone will suppress the adrenal glands.  The higher the dose and the longer the exposure, the more the suppression and the longer it will take for them to come back.  This is why it is often necessary to wean off cortisone or steroids slowly.  I cannot answer how much the cortisone could effect your test results but it certainly can effect the results through several methods.  I would recommend you continue to follow up with your doctor about this to determine the best way to proceed.  As an aside, salivary cortisol levels are not the best way to do these tests.  Blood samples really should be used to guide therapy.  They are much more reliable.  I should be clear that I am not saying the endocrinologist is wrong regarding how the test results are interpreted.  There clearly was not a response from the adrenal gland.  The question is did the adrenal glands get suppressed from the cortisone you are taking and would they respond if you were off the cortisone.  This part needs to be figured out by your doctors.  I would also warn you not to stop taking the cortisone abruptly or without the advice of your doctors as this can be very dangerous if your adrenal glands are not responding appropriately (even life threatening in some cases).  Best wishes.

author: HashiPatient2  Guest Posts: 4 Joined: Mon Sep 15, 2008 8:43 am Gender: Female
title: TPOab Ranges from 3,000 - 6,000
content: Dear Medical Community =)  I was diagnosed with Hashimoto's several years ago. My TPOab was near 6,000.  TSH was in the range that would be considered normal for normal people. I have been taking medication since 2003. My labs have not come back normal once yet.  I still feel like absolute garbage. I hurt all the time. I'm tired all the time. My bones ache and I can't hold information in my head long enough to do basic calculations. Finally, my hair is falling out and my skin has erupted with a vengence, amongst a variety of other symptoms that I don't have the energy to repeat here.  I have attempted to examine these problems from just about every possible medical perspective. I have seen professionals in each of the following fields: general medicine, infectious disease, endocrinology, neurology, rheumatology, gynecology, and dermatology. So far, the only answer they have really offered is that I have Hashimoto's (and an ovarian cyst). Needless to say, that really doesn't help much...  When I ask about why my thryoid antibodies are SO high, I am told, "We don't treat for antibodies, we treat for TSH." While I understand that this is a skillful, but not incorrect evasion of the question =), and while I understand that this is what a large majority of the literature states, I have an absolute need to throw my question out there in the hope of finding SOMEONE who may have, in the course of his or her career, run across SOME obscure study addressing this question definitively or otherwise.  Antibodies are typically made by the body in response to invasive pathogens or in response to inflammatory disease processes, correct? If antibody titres are diagnostically useful in identifying and measuring immune responses to pathogens and inflammatory conditions, (rheumatoid arthritis, for example) then why is it not considered clinically significant in Hashimoto's thryoiditis? Is there a specific reason why A is true in situation 1 and not true in situation 2?  I understand that we can't assume that what is true in one situation can be generalized to suit all situations; yet, it seems this is a question which, in comparison to the more visibly disabling diseases, hasn't been very well studied.  Is there ANYONE out there who can tell me:  (1) Why my antibodies are SO high compared to the average Hashi patient. (2) Why the levels haven't fallen in response to the medication. (3) Why antibodies are considered the cornerstone of diagnosis for this disease, but then are not considered clinically significant in evaluating the progression of this disease. (4) What I should do the next time a doctor tells me that the bone pain is a result of depression =)  Any information you might have (or might have heard of) would be very helpful in directing my efforts to find a treatment that actually makes me feel better.  If anyone is up for a research project, or if you know of anyone who is looking for research subjects, I would truly appreciate the reference!

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: TPOab Ranges from 3,000 - 6,000
content: Hello, Indeed antibodies are produced in most diseases in response to bacterial or other antigens.These can react with the antigen, and can be responsible for their elimination. However in autoimmune disorders like Hashimoto's the antibody is directed to our own tissue and thus are known as auto-antibodies.These only represent the body's altered response and may not always represent the degree of the disease.For example transplacental passage of TPO antibodies do not cause disease in the infant. Although Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and Hashimoto’s disease are autoimmune disorders, there are fundamental differences between them. Like in most autoimmune disorders, there are multiple autoantibodies involved in the case of RA. Although they manifest as synovitis of multiple joints initially, they have actions systemically, affecting various systems as the disease progresses. In contrast, in Hashimoto’s, the thyroid peroxidase antibody is specific only for the throid follicular cells. It causes destruction of the follicles little by little until all the thyroid follicles are destroyed. “Treatment” of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis does not imply that one is treating the autoimmune disorder but, is only to replace the progressively declining thyroid hormone production. Even after all the thyroid follicles are destroyed, the antibodies are known to remain high in some individuals for variable lengths of time. But the good news is that they have no target cells anymore to attack. They are of little or no consequence as far as the rest of the body is concerned. At what point, all the follicles are destroyed in an individual case is open to speculation. Some have postulated that the decreases in TSH levels brought about by the thyroxin therapy may reduce the autoantigenic properties of the thyrocytes with a subsequent decrease in autoantibody titres. Jannson, R., Karlsson, A., and Dahlberg, P.A.: Thyroxine, methimazole, and thyroid microsomal autoantibody titres in hypothyroid Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. Br. Med. J 1985; January 5; 290(6461): 11–12. Best wishes.

title: Re: LUPUS and ANA test results
content: Hello,An ANA positive test could occur in normal persons with out any disease.But then ANA positivity may precede development of auto immune disease.Thus while this test represents one of major criteria for diagnosis for lupus erythematosis yet needs other signs,symptoms for proper diagnosis.Drug induced LE also can show the test positivity.Sjogren's ,Scleroderma,and other connective tissue disease can show positivity.A negative test generally rules out SLE. Thus a clinical correlation is a must for you.Do consult your doctor.

title: Re: frequent/excessive sweating consequences
content: Hello,Excessive sweating is mainly of two types.Focal or primary-generalized or secondary.Palmo- plantar sweating is typical of the primary type and  has a familial basis.Secondary could be due to anxiety state,medications,thyroid disease,tuberculosis, Hodgkin's,HIV disease,cardiac conditions and stroke. author: Mehdy  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Thu Jul 08, 2010 8:47 pm Gender: Male
title: De Quervain thyroiditis.
content: Hello, I'm Mehdy,  I had a subacute thyroiditis last sept.2009, and since then I've become hyperthyroid (subclinical hyperthyroidism, only my TSH is supressed below the normal range). I had thyroid sonography 4months after the onset of my thyroiditis and it showed a small cyst on my right thyroid lobe. I had another one after 3 months and it showed that the cyst had disappeared and there were no other abnormalities on my thyroid. Now almost ten months later after the onset of my disease I'm still in subclinical hyperthyroidism, and I do have all the symptoms of hyperthyroidism except weight loss. Actually I was losing a lot of weight during the acute phase but now it's the complete opposit I'm gaining weight, although, I'm not hypothyroid and I don't have any symptoms of hypothyroidism. (My TSH is still below the normal range, whereas my T4 and T3 hormones are within the normal range)  My questions are:  is it normal to have a cyst during the subacute thyroiditis?  And, is it normal to stay hyperthyroid all this time after the onset of the disease?  Do we recover completely from this kind of thyroiditis or not?  Thank you for reading me.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: De Quervain thyroiditis.
content: Hi, There is no particular reason for cysts to occur in De Quervain's thyroiditis. Disruption of the follicles and hyperemia are the predominant microscopic features of this disease. Rather, it may be fair to say that De Quervain's thyroiditis can occur in thyroid glands with pre-existing cysts. In other words, they may be just incidental findings.  Thyroid nodules are common and are found by clinical palpation in 4-7% of the population and in up to 30-50% in autopsy studies. Approximately 5-10% of the clinically palpable nodules have been shown to be thyroid carcinoma.   Cysts in the thyroid gland can be - pure thyroid cysts, or - Complex cysts (cysts with variable amounts of solid component).   'Complex' cysts account for about 30% of thyroid nodules found on sonography, and pure thyroid cysts comprise < 1%. Most solitary thyroid cysts are derived from hyperplastic nodules and are believed to be a result of cystic change or hemorrhage in pre-existing nodules. Pure cysts are associated with a lower probability of malignancy than mixed cysts.  De Quervain's thyroiditis generally passes through four phases; Hyperthyroid---euthyroid---hypothyroid---- and finally euthyroid. Nearly 90% of patients with this condition recover completely. A minority (5-10%) may remain hypothyroid needing thyroxin replacement. Good luck!

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Suggestions for 23 year old female with low DHEA-S level
content: Hello,DHEA and DHEAS represent the most abundant sex steroid hormone in women and form a large reservoir for production of androgens and estrogens in non-reproductive tissue.As one ages the levels decrease. Observational studies have shown that circulating DHEAS levels below the 10th centile are associated with increased likelihood of low sexual function in both premenopausal and post-menopausal women (Davis et al., 2005)Davis S, Davison S, Donath S, Bell R. Circulating Androgen Levels and Self-reported Sexual Function in Women. JAMA 2005;294:91-96. But as to whether indeed replacement would help in improvement of libido remains unclear.Do get an endrocrinologist's opinion. "Best wishes.

(normally kept very supressed at below 0.1),  T4 <.01, (normally kept on the high end of normal) T3 <.01, (normally kept on the high end of normal) slightly anemic All other CBC readings=normal (white count=normal) All autoimmune tests=negative lymes=negative urine=normal No abnormalities in chest xray slightly elevated BP  I am suffering from the following symptoms:  extreme fatigue low temperature(95-96 F),  periodic feverish spikes paired with dizziness and nausea severe joint pain muscle tension (too tense to shrug shoulders) enlarged lymph nodes behind ears and in the back of neck slight weight gain brittle nails cold sensitivity limbs falling asleep more frequently that usual headaches (near temples) occasional heart fluttering --not frequent VERY lethargic and fatigued insomnia (6 hours of sleep total in past 4 days) decreased appetite indigestion/acid reflux/belching constipation jaw tension  Medical history: Hashimoto's Papillary thyroid carcinoma ADD (hereditary) Endometriosis (diagnosed via laparoscopy) Generalized anxiety/depression *recently recovered from a MRSA infection  Current medications: 200 mcg Levothyroxine (1x daily, taken on empty stomach 1hr before other meds) Birth control pill 50 mg Vyvanse (1x daily, taken after breakfast) 10 mg Zyrtec (1x daily, taken after breakfast) Zyrtec-D (1x daily, taken after breakfast) 37.5 mg Paxil (1x daily, taken after breakfast) *decolonization treatment for MRSA -- hepaclens wash & bactroban swab in nose 2x/day  Social/Lifestyle: 21 y/o Female Single Heterosexual - 1 partner - no risk factors No tobacco use or past use Mild - Moderate alcohol consumption No past or present drug use Live alone Student

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Am I at risk for myxedema coma?
content: Hi, Myxedema coma occurs almost exclusively in persons 60 years and older and in individuals with long-standing hypothyroidism.You have indicated that you had undergone a total thyroidectomy in 2005. Occurs more often during the winter months, which suggests that significant environmental factors such as low temperatures may precipitate decompensation of an underlying compensated hypothyroidism.  None of the signs and symptoms of classic myxedema coma may be present in every case and are non specific. Profound 'coma' is not usual.  As you seem to be living alone, it may not be possible for others to notice anything unusual in you.Therefore you need to be extra-cautious.  You say that your 'endo' monitors you very closely, but you have not indicated what advise you were given following this last report. TSH over 50 mU/L is too high. Have you been taking your thyroid medications regularly??  Remember that hypothermia is defined as core temperatures  < 35ºC. Oral or axillary temperatures are unreliable. Low reading rectal thermometers are reliable and may help to alert you. Hypothermia may be classified as,    Mild hypothermia - Core temperature 32 to 35ºC (90 to 95ºF) Moderate hypothermia - Core temperature 28 to 32ºC (82 to 90ºF) Severe hypothermia - Core temperature below 28ºC (82ºF).  Patients with myxedema coma have a temperature below 37°C (98.6°F) in approximately 15% of cases. 15% of patients may have a temperatures < 29.5°C (85°F).    Whenever there is any doubt about a change in mental status, formal mental status testing should be performed. It is recommended that physicians should also be alert to the possibility of depression in the seemingly demented patient and perform depression screening in any patient with mental status changes.  Therefore, it is better for you to get periodically followed up by one regular doctor who is familiar with your baseline mental status (to obviate confusions arising in case of an unforeseen emergency).You should consult your 'endo' as soon as you can with the latest report. In future, take your thyroid medications regularly and work with your doctor to keep your TSH at a satisfactory level. Non compliance will certainly put you at risk of myxedema coma. A review by your psychiatrist also will be immensely helpful.    Good luck!

title: Re: TSH/HOMOCYSTEINE
content: Hello,Your doctor was right in reducing synthyroid due to low TSH.A serum TSH result between 0.5 and 2.0 mIU/L is generally considered the therapeutic target for a standard LT4 replacement dose for primary hypothyroidism.Your homocysteine  levels are increased. Though it is not proved beyond doubt, this is said to be associated with increased incidence of atherosclerosis,deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.Greater than 100 micromoles is considered severe in blood samples.This aminoacid is broken down with the help of vitamins like B12 ,B6,And folic acid.If there is deficiency of these vitamins,when corrected would lower the levels.Genetic forms do occur but rare. title: Re: TSH/HOMOCYSTEINE
content: Hi ohaedo, Your blood indices indicate a macrocytosis and your RBC count is low. As Dr.Jagesh has alluded to, Vitamin B12 deficiency must be excluded (and corrected promptly if present), as your serum homocystine levels are raised.   Your profile indicates that your mother has a schizoaffective disorder (which has a genetic background). Therefore, it becomes all the more important for you to avoid vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiencies. Discuss with your doctor and have your vitamin B12 and folic acid levels checked soon. Good luck!

content: Hello,Phytoestrogens include isoflavones,coumestans and lignans.These have been identified in vegetables,fruits,and whole grains.These have weak estrogenic activity.Some studies have proven their efficacy in menopausal syndromes,cancers,and as antioxidants.Benefits are seen regarding hypercholesterolaemia. title: Flushed face, sometimes sweating, cannot find a trigger
content: My spouse is a 26 year old (male).  Since the age of 12 or 13 he has had increasing problems with what we have come to call "hot face".  At any time, for no reason we can determine, his face will become overly flushed, burning, and on terrible days will sweat profusely.  The heat is centered high on his cheeks, around his nose and sinus areas.  It can be certain foods (which changes all the time), high or low stress, in or out of public, warm or cold weather.  The only definite time we have found it to be the worst is when he is coming down with a cold, but that does not at all explain the times he is feeling perfectly healthy.  He is just over 6'1" tall, very fair skin and burns easily in the sun, and is not overweight.  As a child they first said he would grow out of it.  He was then treated with allergy injections weekly which had noeffect.  He has had a mild tinea infection which we have been treating.  It flares in heat but there is no correlation to his "hot face".  He does have asthma and in the last year has been on Advair twice daily.  We have had some luck with GABA and primrose as herbals but they are no longer effective in reducing the hotface.  In the last year, dark purple striae have appeared on his upper inner thighs.  He will no longer go out in public for fear of thing flaring up, and has a hard time eating not knowing when he will be in intolerable discomfort.  He spends many evenings and days with cold-packs or ice on his face for relief.  We have thought of hyperhydrosis, Cushings, allergy, social anxiety, etc and are lost as to what may be causing his issue.  I hope there may be some insight or help for him.

title: Black outs, weakness, low sugar
content: I'm a 21 year old female. 5'8" 140 lbs. I constantly feel weak, tired and just like I'm running on E. Sometimes if I stand up and still for extended amounts of time (and by extended this could be waiting 10 minutes in a long line or taking a 30minute shower) I find myself getting dizzy and lightheaded. When this happens I usually have about 5 minutes post the onset of those feelings to take a seat or else I really start to blackout. Two weeks ago however, I was getting some lunch and waiting in a long line. The lightheaded feeling popped up out of no where (I felt pretty good before that, not even hungry but it was time to eat). After getting the feeling I was unconscious in less than one minute. I was only out for a few seconds and started feeling better immediately. People around me helped until the paramedics came. Someone had me eat a bite of cookie while I waited. Once the paramedics arrived they took my sugar and it was 60 which they said was below normal and gave me a coke. 15 minutes later it was 79 and they let me go. I felt better. I had eaten 3-4 hours earlier (some rice and shrimp, water). I've been feeling especially weak ever since and it seems sort of independent of whether or not I eat (eating helps if it's like a serious meal, snacks and small meals do little). I've made sure to include proteins and whole grains in my meals. Other information:  I was vegetarian for 2.5 years, carefully watching my eating habits and getting a good range of proteins and vegetables (I ate dairy and eggs).  I have recently incorporated fish and seafood back into my diet wondering if that might help me be more energetic (although this has been an on and off problem for much of my life, including when I ate all kinds of meat).  I was tested for iron deficiency about 1.5 years ago and was found to be slightly anemic but the follow up testing a year later said I was fine and I was taken off iron supplements (I cant say that I felt any different while taking the supplements).  I like to be active. I play a varsity sport at my college but this problem makes it difficult to walk around, let alone run and sprint. The problem is on and off but has recently been quite bothersome. I have made a doctor's appointment.

title: Re: increased adrenaline production - why?
content: Hello,The test for catecholamines may be affected by vigorous exercise.Also consumption of tea,coffee,banana,vanilla,citrus fruits could vary the results.Medications should be continued unless specifically asked by the physician to withdraw.These may include caffeine, Tylenol,nicotinic acid,levodopa etc. Severe anxiety states can show increase in these levels.Most important would be to rule out pheochromocytomas which are rare chromaffin cell tumors.Most of these are benign.Familial syndromes are known.The reason to recognize them is due to the fact that we can avoid potential life threatening hypertension, and also because they could be cured.Headache,palpitations,anxiety and hypertension are few of the symptoms and presentations.Urinary catecholamines,and imaging studies are the main relevant tests.Surgical resection is the treatment of choice.Medical treatment is treatment of hypertension. I will give you a bit of a time line of events leading up to my diagnosis of GAD.  3 years old- corrective surgery for undescended testes.(successful on right side) 8 years old- corrective surgery for left side undescended teste.(not successful) 13 years old- put on a hormone therapy to help coerce puberty with one immature teste. 16 years old- left side orchiectomy and insertion of prosthetic teste. (due to microlithiasis) 36 years old- put on hormone replacement therapy indefinetly  I had a panic attack in October of 2009 and (never had one before) thought I was having the big one (family history of heart attacks) rushed to emergency plugged into all the machines, ecg comes back just fine, everything settles down and I am released. My question is this, could a lifetime of likely having very low testosterone levels be blamed for my anxiety issues? Are there other tests I should insist upon getting done? title: hyperthyroidsm/vitamin D deficiency
content: I’m 24 now. I had my baby in 2007. After having the baby I was depressed like for a week what I think the so called postpartum depression. Well that went away but my tiredness didn’t I was sleepy all the time. In May 2009 I felt a groin in my throat I was going through some stress but it went away by itself after a month. In August 14, 2009 I had a surgery done a bilateral removal of breast lumps, 1 in my right and 2 in my left. I fainted right after the surgery when the nurses put me to walk so I could of go home, they didn’t do any test as of whey I fainted, I went home after that cause I didn’t faint again. After a week of the surgery I started to get depressed I was dizzy I was sleeping almost all day and night I wasn’t eating properly, I didn’t have interest in anything. Mid August I went to Tijuana, MX. And decided to get a thyroid test well it came out that I was hyperthyroidism. My groin came back it was bothering me in my throat.  I started on medication by the end of August I don’t remember the name but I was on 5mg 3 times a day. I decided to see a doctor here in California for that so I could of get medication from a local pharmacy. I went to a new doctor in January 2010 he did another test and change my medication told me to continue taking it and get rechecked in 3 weeks. author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: hyperthyroidsm/vitamin D deficiency
content: Hi, Your symptoms are too non specific to attribute to any particular diagnosis. The one thing that appears certain is that you seem to be suffering from repeated intestinal parasitic infection. Although you had tested positive for amebiasis on more than one occasion since childhood, other helminthic infestations also must be sought. In chronic cases, often there is a paucity of symptoms.There is some evidence that thyroid status influences metabolism of vitamin D. Some workers recommend vitamin D supplementation in both hyper as well as hypothyroid states.  It is well known that chronic amebiasis and especially giardiasis in children often cause malabsorbtion and stunted growth.  Several years prior to the AIDS epidemic, many gay men became infected by intestinal parasites which previously had occurred mostly in the tropics. These diseases, notably amebiasis and giardiasis, started to spread via sexual transmission, to infect as many as 60% of gay men. Once infected, persons can carry the parasites for years unless they detected and treated. Many gay men show only minimal symptoms or none at all and can infect others.   These parasites are believed to act as "cofactors" which do not cause AIDS, but may make it more likely that exposure to the HIV infection will develop into the disease. Some experts believe that the continuing epidemic of parasites among gay men has been a cofactor for AIDS and a major factor responsible for its spread.Fortunately, the sexually transmitted amebiasis is less virulent than the strains found in the tropics, and respond to milder drugs, such as humatin (paromomycin).  There is reasonable body of evidence indicating that helminthiasis is also responsible for the unrelenting prevalence of AIDS and tuberculosis in developing, particularly African, countries. A review of data from several studies clearly indicates that effective treatment of helminth infection reduces HIV progression by decreasing the viral load, thus improving helminth-induced immune suppression.  It is at times overlooked that treatment of the whole family is ideal in treating intestinal helminthic infestations. As sexually transmitted amebisis and giardiasis have become a reality, it may also be beneficial to investigate and treat the sexual partners as well for achieving better cure rates. Good luck!

title: Pregnant, hypothyroid, rapidly rising tsh, dose question
content: Hi There,  My name is Amanda, I am a 28 year old female currently in my 8th week of my  4th pregnancy with 2 live children and 1 miscarriage recently. During my miscarriage, my tsh rose to 3.49 before my doctor increased my Synthroid dosage from 50mcg to 75mcg. Following the miscarriage, my tsh dropped all the way to 0.03 where it was when I got pregnant again. My dr. had me decrease my Synthroid dosage back to 50mcg daily. In less than 2 weeks, my tsh went from 0.03 to 0.54. I then upped my dosage to 50mcg for two days and then 75mcg on the third day. 19 days later, my tsh is at 2.73 and I am concerned with how rapidly it is rising. I am feeling very hypo again. My dr, unfortunately thinks that this is still normal, but I'm concerned with both the rate it is rising and the level it is at. I want to increase my dosage again, but she isn't convinced. I live in Canada and am seeing a family practitioner who refuses to refer me to an endocrinologist because she feels my tsh is within the normal range. I am working hard on a referral, but don't want to ignore my rising tsh in the meantime.   I know that progressive testing with T3 and T4 would be the most helpful in order to come to a firm conclusion, but unfortunately my dr. won't do this testing as she feels TSH is a good enough gauge so I don't have those numbers for you.  Should I increase my dose? If so, what would you consider a reasonable increase that will likely lower my tsh to within the 1-2 range? And, is my tsh level of 2.73 dangerous as far as the pregnancy goes? I really don't want to have another miscarriage. I have had one ultrasound already a week ago with a strong heartbeat if that helps at all.  Thank-you so much for your help.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Pregnant, hypothyroid, rapidly rising tsh, dose question
content: Hi, It is not advisable to try and correct the TSH levels in pregnancy without knowledge about the FT4 levels. TSH levels take time to change following dosage adjustments of thyroxin, and harm may be done to the growing fetus in the interim.   Both maternal hypo and hyperthyroidism are not good for the fetus as well as the mother but, between them, hyperthyroidism perhaps is more harmful from the point of view of the fetus. Therefore, rather than to risk pushing oneself into a hyperthyroid state, it is imperative that any changes in thyroxin dosage during pregnancy, should only be guided only by FT4 levels. Good luck!

title: Sudden overwhelming drowsiness followed by 'hangover'
content: Hello - I've been experiencing this issue off and on for several years and have had glucose level testing done which has always come back normal.  However, during my last pregnancy, I failed the glucose tolerance test by a small amount (can't remember the actual numbers at this point since it's been 12 years or so!).  My thyroid was removed and I've been taking 12.5 mcg of liothyronine and 1.0 mg of levothyroxine daily for years, with TSH in low-normal range and T3/T4 levels stable.  Typically, the scenario has been that I'd eat a meal and within 10-15 minutes, I'd be unable to stay awake, feeling a slight nausea and an overwhelming need to sleep.  If I tried to fight it, I would just feel sicker and sicker, then I'd fall asleep.  The sleep is deep.  I'd almost equate it to general anaesthesia where you are there and then you're not.  The sleep seems to last about an hour or sometimes more.  If I am roused during the sleep, I wake feeling groggy, with a headache, fogged thinking, feeling completely drained of energy and an undercurrent of nausea.  It reminds me of the few college-aged hangovers I had.  That feeling is difficult to overcome, sometimes for hours.  I altered my diet somewhat and the symptoms went away.  However, I've returned to less careful eating and I've experienced the "crash" again.  What troubles me more is that the most recent events have occurred without the typical meal first.  In the past month, I believe I've had this occur at least four times without having had a meal, usually in the mid-afternoon 3-4PM, long after lunch and before supper.  I know my PCP will be happy to try more bloodwork but it's been normal forever and he doesn't especially dig around and look for alternatives once the bloodwork shows up alright.  If I can have some additional possible insights, I know he'd pursue them with me.  Thank you for any suggestions!

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Sudden overwhelming drowsiness followed by 'hangover'
content: Hello,Obstuctive sleep apnea is an important problem affecting diabetics,people with obesity,and cardiovascular disease.This is now being recognized as one of the important causes of daytime sleeping and a risk factorfor adverse CVS events.The shared risk is obesity.This is caused tdue to airway obstruction during sleep.Tonsillar enlargement,abnormal anatomy of air ways,alcohol,sleeping position,insulin resistance,metabolic syndrome,diabetic autonomic neuropathy all may contribute to this condition.Overnight polysomnography in a sleep lab would be diagnostic.Continuous airway pressure therapy,treatment of obesity,treatment of nasal allergy,dental appliances and rarely uvulopalatopharyngoplasty are the treatment modalities. Best wishes.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: High anti-thyroid antibodies, but no reference range given
content: Hi, In the not so distant past, elevated TSH and Antithyroid microsomal antibodies (TMAb) were considered the gold standard for the diagnosis of chronic autoimmune (Hashimoto's) thyroiditis. despite the presence of contaminating antigens in the preparations. Thyroid peroxidase (TPO), a large, membrane-associated glycoprotein expressed only in the thyrocytes, is an important enzyme involved in the multistep thyroid hormone synthesis. It is the major autoantigen in the thyroid microsomal particle. Assays for Thyroid peroxidase antibody (TPOAb) are now available and this has rendered TMAb obsolete.  Antithyroid microsomal antibodies in titers greater than 1:6,400 are strongly suggestive of chronic autoimmune (Hashimoto) thyroiditis or Graves disease (GD). TPOAb in excess of 200 IU per mL, strongly suggests Hashimoto's thyroiditis. 57-74% of patients with Graves' disease also show high values.   TMAb titers >1:100 are found in 10-13% of elderly women (mean age 80 years)and 3% of elderly men, but titers >1:6400 are present in only 1% of normal individuals.  Detection of TPOAb is strong evidence against a goiter being due to non-autoimmune causes of hypothyroidism. The risk for the development of hypothyroidism is 3% to 4% per year if TPOAb are present and TSH is elevated.   By the way, do you have a goiter? You should get your TPOAb levels checked, to be sure. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: potassium levels
content: Hi, It is not clear how it came to be known that your intracellular Potassium(K+) levels are low. These are not measured routinely. Are your renal functions OK?. What about other serum electrolytes (esp, bicarbonate)?  What is the blood pH? What is the serum osmolality?  Most of the total body K+ is intracellular. This pool acts as a buffer to prevent sudden, wide fluctuations of the serum levels which can have deleterious effects on the heart. Intracellular shift of the serum K+ and renal excretion of potassium under aldosterone influence are the chief ways the body gets rid of excess serum K+. This mechanism is well developed in humans. However, there is no well developed renal mechanism for conservation of K+.    Normal adult values for serum K+ range from 3.5 to 5.5 mmol/L. Serum K+ concentrations may not be an accurate indicator of total body stores, as intracellular K+ accounts for 98% of total body amount.Serum K+ levels below 3.5 and above 5.5 mmol/L have traditionally been labeled as hypokalemia and hyperkalemia, respectively.Serum K+  above 6.5 mEq/L is associated with significant morbidity and mortality and should be handled as an emergency.  In routine clinical situations, whenever high values for serum K+ are encountered, the technique of blood specimen collection needs to be first looked into. 'Pseudohyperkalemia' is an in vitro phenomenon (i.e., the in vivo serum K+ is normal). This is caused by the release of K+ from cellular elements of blood during the process of clotting and, less commonly, by the release of K+ from ischemic muscle cells due to tight tourniquet or hand/arm exercise during the procedure. If the latter is suspected, blood should be drawn in a proper manner again and serum K+ repeated. If the former is suspected, the platelet and white cell counts should be checked, and serum should be inspected for significant hemolysis (hemolized sample). Hyperkalemia occurs when there is thrombocytosis (platelet count greater than 600,000), leukocytosis (WBC greater than 200,000) or significant hemolysis (serum hemoglobin greater than 1.5 g/dl). In cases of pseudohyperkalemia, the plasma K+ (unclotted blood), as opposed to serum K+, will be normal.  Hemolysis may occur during sample collection due to, - rapid aspiration of blood through a narrow-gauge needle,and - excessive agitation of blood samples.  To prevent false results, phlebotomy personnel should not rapidly aspirate blood through a narrow-gauge needle or excessively agitate blood samples.   Hyperkalemia associated with normal total body K+ is caused by the shifts of K+ out of the cell and is commonly seen in acidemia, sudden increases in plasma osmolality, massive tissue breakdown and, in very rare circumstances, adrenergic blockade and hyperkalemic periodic paralysis.  Gordon's syndrome or Familial hyperkalemia and hypertension (FHH; pseudohypoaldosteronism type II) is an autosomal dominant disorder featuring hyperkalemia, hypertension, and low renin. Hypercalciuria accompanies hyperkalemia, and both precede hypertension. The mean time between detection of hyperkalemia and appearance of hypertension was seen to be 13 yrs in some studies.  Several HIV-1 proteins have been shown to perturb membrane permeability and ion transport. Unexplained hyperkalemia persisting despite normal cortisol response to ACTH may represent hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism, which has been described in hospitalized patients with HIV disease. Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism may occur with several other conditions as well.  Chewing tobacco contains a significant amount of potassium. A case of severe hyperkalemia in a patient undergoing chronic hemodialysis due to tobacco chewing has been reported.  [Fan K, Leehey DJ. Orange juice-induced hyperkalemia in a diabetic patient with chronic renal failure. Diabetes Care. 1996 Dec;19(12):1457-8].  Without much by way of history to go by and with lack of details regarding other laboratory tests, i can't be more specific. As you indicate that you had meningitis in the recent past (2008), you need to have your serum osmolality checked. You may consider discussing with your doctor about being referred to a neurologist for a consultation. I hope this information is of help. Best wishes!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Just had thyroidectomy, how long til Hypothyroidizm?
content: Hi, You have not indicated if radioactive iodine ablation (to destroy the thyroid remnant, if any) has been planned.  For effective radioiodine ablation, it is necessary to obtain high iodine uptake levels by the thyroid remnant after surgery. To achieve this, the thyroid hormone suppression therapy (THST) must not be started immediatly after surgery. The delay in initiation of the thyroid hormone therapy after the total thyroidectomy brings about the progressive increase of the Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH)  serum levels. Maximal TSH stimulation is necessary to ensure that any remnant of thyroid gland will avidly take up the radioiodine and thus get destroyed in the process. The half-life of T4 is 5-7 days; the half-life of T3 is only 1 day. Most investigators consider that serum TSH levels needed to obtain this stimulus of the thyroid tissue is typically achieved in 4 to 6 weeks(TSH levels higher than 25-30 mUI/l).  The main problem with this approach is that the hypothyroid symptoms that the patients develop is often too distressing. A newer approach tries to overcome this problem in a way that patients can be started on (or continue) thyroxin therapy and still undergo thyroid ablation with radioiodine. This has become possible with the introduction of  Recombinant human TSH (rhTSH).    Thyrotropin alfa was initially approved in the US in 1998 and Europe in 2001 for use as a diagnostic tool in the management of patients being tested for the recurrence of well-differentiated thyroid cancer.  In December 2007, the US Federal Drug Administration(FDA) approved the use of rhTSH for adjuvant treatment with radioiodine in patients with differentiated thyroid cancers (DTC) without evidence of metastasis.  Recombinant human TSH (rhTSH) has been found to be an effective and safe alternative to thyroid hormone withdrawal during the post-surgical management of papillary and follicular thyroid cancer.  You may discuss with your surgeon as to whether this alternative modality is suitable for you and also the expenses involved. rhTSH is fairly expensive and some insurance plans may not cover this treatment. Best wishes!

title: does losing alot of blood at onset of puberty limit growth?
content: or possibly delay it?  I was admitted like 6 or 7 times in a span of a year to a hospital because my parents thought i was out of control because of some mental illness so they took me to inpatient mental units of hospitals  this happened when I was 12-13, right before or at the onset of puberty  do you think losing that much blood(4 or 8 cylinders at a time, 6 or 7 times over a year) can stunt my growth  or cause me to be anemic?  i am now 16 and i am not as developed as i would like to be i also feel fatigued often
posted_time: Post  by dhan127@gmail.com » Sat Oct 31, 2009 10:03 pm

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: does losing alot of blood at onset of puberty limit growth?
content: Hello, No, this would not inhibit or delay your growth.  Anemia can be checked easily so if you believe your fatigue may be caused by this, have it tested.  In the meantime it can't hurt to eat foods that are high in iron such as whole grains, meats, egg yolks, dark veggies and beans, apricots and raisins.    The amounts of blood taken for testing - even multiple vials - does not amount to enough to cause anemia.  Your stature has a lot to do with your genetic makeup so if your parents are short, you may be as well.  There is not much you can do to change that.  Also, the onset of your periods often results in no further height growth.  Puberty age and growth varies with the individual.  You might schedule a well child exam with your doctor to review your growth patterns, puberty and family health history.  Best wishes.
posted_time: Post  by Debbie Miller, RN » Tue Aug 24, 2010 6:10 pm

title: -estadiol, +prolactin, +triglyceride, little or no periods
content: I recently visited my primary doctor and told her that for the past ten months I have had little to no peiords.  Around the beginning of 2010 I was experiencing bad mood swings, almost incontrollable anger.  At that point, I had switched my birth control from Levora to Yaz, my doctor explaining that it had the least amount of estrogen.  For a while I seemed better, although I have had vaginal dryness and little to no libido for the entire 10 months.  At the beginning of the summer I began to feel the bad mood swings again as well as depression (equal to the days of my raging hormone teenage years) and could not understand what is wrong with me besides an unequatable amount of stress.  Bloodwork showed normal FSH, LH, & TSH levels.  These have all stayed normal with test dates of 4/31/2009, 8/10/10 & 8/18/10.  However, my estadiol level went from 69.9 on 4/31/09 to 9.0 on 8/10/10 and 12.0 on 8/18/10.  My prolactin levels were 9.94 on 4/31/09 to 26.58 on 8/10/10 and 25.82 on 8/18/10.  Even though the prolactin levels are borderline, I feel that something is definitely amiss.  I have noticed that my nails are quite brittle and my triglyceride levels are twice the norm in the 250's.  I am 26 and eat well and exercise regularly.  My doctor tells me that even though my e2 levels are in the menopause range, the LH and FSH levels do not reflect a premenopausal woman.  I have to wait for awhile to get in with an endo and am very anxious in the meantime to know what the possibilities could be. My research has pointed to a prolactinoma, but my boss (a neurosurgeon) tells me that my prolactin would be in the 100's.  I didn't know if being on Yaz was somehow keeping my hormone levels at a more normal level though.    ANY information you can give me would be greatly appreciated!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: hypothyroidsm
content: Hi, You have not indicated what your symptoms(other than a weight gain) are and if you have a goiter and if any thyroid FNAC had been performed(and the report).  It’s estimated that TPO antibodies are detectable in approximately 95% of patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.Therefore,< 5% of the patients with this condition may not have elevated antibody levels.  Vitamin B12 (cyanocobalamin) deficiency occurs in about 3-4%  of the general population.Pernicious anemia (PA) is present more frequently in subjects with primary autoimmune hypothyroidism with some reports indicative of association in up to 12% of patients. Non autoimmune causes of B12 deficiency also may be associated in hypothyroid patients and this association has not been studied in detail and may vary according to dietary habits in different populations.Some of the symptoms (weakness, numbness,paraesthesia, and poor memory) can occur in both hypothyroidism and vitamin B12 deficiency. Anaemia with or without macrocytosis, tends to occur later in B12 deficiency and may even be absent.In one study, a significant symptomatic improvement was observed within 3-6 months of initiating B12 treatment in hypothyroid individuals with low B12 levels.  Hashimoto's thyroiditis: Management of patients with overt hypo-thyroidism is straight forward.  In patients with an elevated TSH level and a normal thyroxine (T4) level (subclinical hypothyroidism), indications for treatment are not very clear. If the TSH level is greater than 20 mU per mL (20 mU per L) with a normal T4 level, there is a high probability that the patient will develop hypothyroidism. If the TSH level is elevated but is less than 20 mU per mL and the antimicrosomal antibody titer is greater than 1:1,600, hypothyroidism is likely to develop in 80% of patients. Therefore, in patients with a serum TSH level greater than 10 mU per mL (10 mU per L) with symptoms suggestive of hypothyroidism, and in patients with a high risk of progression to hypothyroidism (e.g., those with high antibody titers) , it is recommended that treatment be initiated. As for the others, because of the risk of developing hypothyroidism, annual assessment of thyroid function is indicated. (Sakiyama R. Thyroiditis: a clinical review. Am Fam Physician 1993;48:615-21).  As your post lacks details, i can't be more specific.It may not be a bad idea, to have your vitamin B12 levels checked as well. I hope this information is of help. Best wishes!

title: Growth plates "closing"
content: I have a question concerning growth plates. I am 4'9 and my husband is 6'2. I have a 13 (almost 14) year old son whom I have taken to two different endocrologist. He is very short his current height is 5'. Both endocrologist said there is no hormone defiency so they will not do GH therapy. I recently took him to a bone & joint clinic for knee and elbow problems the dr. said his growth plates are "closing" I asked if that means he is finished growing he said not nessecilary. Well this news comes as a great concern to me! I know that when they close no further growth is possible. I aslo understand he is going to be short, but the endocronoligist said between 5'2 & 5'9. My question is how much more potential growth is possible once the plates satrt "closing"? Is it now too late for GH therapy? Isn't 13/14 a little early for this process to be staring? He is going thru  puberty hair under arms, voice change ect. I have an appt with the endocrologist in 3 weeks, thats the soonest I can get him in. I feel like every day is time passing that we may need! Please advise a very worried mother what to do. Thanks!
posted_time: Post  by okiegirl1972 » Tue Nov 03, 2009 2:23 pm

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Growth plates "closing"
content: Hi, You say - (recently took him to a bone & joint clinic for knee and elbow problems the dr. said his growth plates are "closing").I presume that X-Rays of the elbow and knee were obtained and the doctor based his observation from these films.  It would have been very helpful if you had given the reason for his joint problem.  Hand bone age measurements are a commonly utilized modality for assessing skeletal maturity in children.  In the evaluation of the risk of curve progression in idiopathic scoliosis however(Because spine films are not sensitive enough to measure the progression of skeletal maturity during the rapid growth phase of adolescence),many orthopedic surgeons use radiographs of the elbow (method of Sauvegrain1).  Bone growth occurs at the epiphysial plate.Growth in height of an individual is a sum of the growth of the long bones in the lower limb,the bones of the vertebral column and the skull.  How much an individual is expected to grow in height per year can not be unfortunately predicted accurately by dividing the known 'average' increase in the height of a group of individuals at (say,25 years of age) by  number of years.  This is because bone growth (velocity of growth) is neither uniform, nor linear.Bones grow more rapidly during adolescence and thereafter, the velocity declines.  The examples sited below(observations from some studies) may be more informative...     "Overall, approximately 70% of growth in the femur occurs at the distal growth plate. The proportion of growth occurring in the distal femoral growth plate in girls varies from 60% at seven years of age to 90% at age 14. Similarly, the contribution of the distal femoral growth plate in boys varies from 55% at seven years of age to 90% at age 16. Overall, the contribution of the proximal tibial growth plate is approximately 57%. In girls, this varies from 50% at seven years of age to 80% at age 14. In boys it varies from 50% at seven years of age to 80% at age 16".   From the age of seven to skeletal maturity, the distal femur contributes approximately 1.3 cm per year to femoral growth, except in the last two years, when it contributes half that amount.  Another example: "The long bones displayed decelerating growth through time, with greater velocities for the larger lower limb (vs. smaller upper limb) bones and the larger proximal (vs. smaller distal) elements within limbs. Coordination for bone size and growth velocity is good both within and between limbs, suggesting a common growth control mechanism that should make growth prediction possible. Adjusted for size, the tibia appears to be the most variable of these four long bones, which may be due to a combination of environmental effects and flexible growth potential". Am. J. Hum. Biol. 16:648-657, 2004. © 2004  The aforesaid observations hopefully make it abundantly clear that growth in height of an individual is complex,various bones contributing varying proportions at varying times to the overall growth.  To conclude,it appears that in a given 'individual',it may be extremely difficult to accurately predict the final height he/she may achieve! Good day!

author: mcbobbin  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Sun Aug 15, 2010 10:31 pm Gender: Female
title: fatigue, migraines, joint pain, heart palp, no DX
content: For the past 3 years I have struggled to function in my job and personal life while dealing with nearly daily symptoms of extreme fatigue to the point I find myself planning activities that don't require physical exertion, but ironically with severe insomnia.   At least weekly I also have severe migraine type headaches that cause blurred vision in only one eye at a time, with a grey "shadowy" vision out of that eye, which causes nausea and light and sound sensitivity.  In addition to the fatigue, in the past 2-3 years, I have developed significant joint pain particularly in my knees, which worsens both when I attempt to exercise, as well as if I stay stationary for over 1 hour. I had begun yoga to attempt to strengthen my supporting muscles, but after 8 months of yoga, the only outcome is that now my knees seem to slide out of their joints at times, and now my left fingers have begun to show the same stiffness and searing pain.  Whether this is significant at all I'm not sure. But I am always insatiably thirsty. If I am on a long commute and realize I have forgotten my drinks, I must stop and buy up to 3-4 bottles of water or gatorade to last me 1-3 hours. Despite this, my urine is typically cloudy, and I have had 4 kidney stones in the past 2 years.  Because of the fatigue, sluggishness, mental fog, almost chronic yeast infections, inability to focus at times, and itchy dry skin, as well as the significant family history, my PCP has done 3 thyroid tests which are at worst on the low end of normal. So that has been ruled out.  I have been developing new symptoms in the past year such as daily nausea intermittently during the day EVERY day, "thoracic outlet syndrome", tingling and "pins and needles" feelings in my left hand, and an odd heart sensation. At least weekly, I have an odd experience that my heart is completely skipping a beat or two. This is followed my a deep hollow thump (felt and heard at times) and the feeling that all of the air has temporarily been sucked out of my lungs.  Additionally, I have been gaining weight. I started a diet of 1400-1600 calories per day, high in protiens, fiber, and fruit and veggies. After 7 months of this diet, along with exercise, I had only lost 5 pounds.  I am a mental health therapist, and am aware of how emotions can affect somatic symptoms. However, I am not experiencing panic attacks, anxiety, or depression, except for the frustration that I feel each time I go to a doctor only to hear them tell me I should be "Happy" that all the tests come back normal. Ironically, I'd rather have a diagnosis at this time than to have normal test results.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Thyroid levels increased substantially within 2 days of test
content: Hi, This query touches upon two important aspects related to thyroid function testing. - relationship of TSH levels to food intake and - timing of the testing.  Firstly, as far as T3 and T4 measurements are concerned, blood may be drawn at any time of the day without fasting. TSH levels also may be measured at any time of the 'day' without the need to fast.  Like other pitutary hormones(such as growth hormone) that show a circadian variation, TSH also shows a fairly consistent pattern of variations during a 24 hour period.  TSH appears to be secreted in a dual fashion, a) in intermittent  pulses(bursts) which constitute 60-70% of the total amount secreted and b) a background continuous apulsatile(tonic) secretion (30-40%). The pulses occur roughly every 2-3 hours(subject to variations). Occurrence of these spurts are difficult to pin point accurately.  Several studies indicate that the maximum TSH levels occurs just before a person falls asleep.The levels thereafter tend to maintain during the night, with mean values of 1.34 mu/ml.The serum TSH levels begin to fall the next morning from 8 a.m. to 11 a.m.Thereafter, the level tends to remain low during the rest of the day (mean serum TSH value of 0.85 μU/ml). No relationship between meals and the variation of the TSH level has been noted. The circadian rhythm of serum TSH is not only of physiological interest but has also the practical implications in that, blood sample collections for TSH determinations are best performed at 11 a.m, when the TSH level has fallen to the average daytime levels.  Thus one can appreciate that although TSH,T3 and T4 may be performed at any time of the day and without fasting, there is a valid point in performing TSH testing during the forenoon hours.  You have unfortunately not included your laboratory's normal reference ranges.  Since late 2002, the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (AACE) revised the normal range to 0.3-3.0 for serum TSH levels.Prior to 2002, the commonly used range was 0.5-5.0. As explained earlier, TSH levels must not be interpreted in isolation.  You have not mentioned at what time of the day (or night) your blood samples were drawn and whether both times the samples were collected at the same time of the day/night or otherwise. Also, you have not mentioned about having any complaints suggestive of hypothyroidism, i take it that you are perhaps don't have them.Your TSH levels were within normal reference range. But, some endocrinologists would prefer to treat patients with TSH levels >2 if the symptoms and clinical features are so compelling to suggest hypothyroidism. Best wishes!

title: Vasopressin Mystery?
content: My 22mth old daughter was being tested for DI, because she was always thirsty, and uriniating large amounts. She had the water deprivation test. Throughout the test, her nephrologist was very pleased with the results he was getting, and said he was 99% sure that everything was fine, and she definitely didn't have DI. However, the full report will be back in 3-4wks.  I recieved a call that just like the nephrologist stated before, her urine and blood was concentrated like it should be, BUT somehow her vasopressin levels were almost non-exsistent. They should be normal as well. I was told that the renal team will be conversing with the endocrinology team, and getting back to me, since this is "perplexing."  My question is, how could her concentration be so normal, if there was no vasopressin? What is helping her concentrate? Is this a sign there is something wrong with her pitituary or hypothalmus? (excuse the spelling)  I know the doctors will explain things to me, but I hate going in blind, and I need something to go on here! Any help would be appreciated! Thank you!
posted_time: Post  by AMH61805 » Sun Aug 01, 2010 7:17 pm

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Vasopressin Mystery?
content: Hello,Why the child has passed the water deprivation test despite deficient in AVP(ArginineVasoPressin)?Obviously there must be some vasopressin like substance.In condition(Which is very rare)Autosomal Recessive Familial Diabetes Insipidus the parentsare normal to water deprivation.The child remains aysmptomatic for the first year with no normal AVP. But there is a compensatory response from a mutated hormone Leu-AVP.Measured with radioimmunoassay the levels were increased 30 times normal,thereby suggesting that unknown mechanisms might partially compensate the deficiency of AVP in very young children.  (Ref-Human Molecular Genetics Volume 8, Number 7 Pp. 1303-1307)- Autosomal Recessive Familial Neurohypophyseal Diabetes Insipidus with Continued Secretion of Mutant Weakly Active Vasopressin. Michael D. Willcutts, Eric Felner and Perrin C. White+  Division of Pediatric Endocrinology, University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, 5323 Harry Hines Boulevard, Dallas, TX 75235-9063, USA   Hope this information is useful in your discussions.Best wishes.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: unexplained symptoms, possible hypothyroidism vs vit def.
content: Hi, Hypothyroidism may be - primary (due to a throid disorder), - secondary (due to a pitutary disorder), or - tertiary (due to an hypothalamic disorder).  The secondary and tertiary types together are known as central hypothyroidism.   Your FT4 is closer to the lower limit of the normal range and the TSH (thyroid stimulating hormone), although within range, appears to be inappropriately low for the level of the FT4.This kind of a thyroid profile is seen in secondary or tertiary hypothyroidism.   To differentiate primary from tertiary hypothyroidism, a TRH(thyrotropin releasing hormone) stimulation test may at times help.In this test, the TSH response is studied following an injection of TRH. If there is absolutely no increase in TSH, it indicates secondary hypothyroidism. It there is a delayed and attenuated response (at at 60-180 minutes), this indicates a tertiary hypothyroidism. In primary hypothyroidism and normal controls, TSH rises in about 20-30 minutes.But this test is not a good discriminator in distinguishing between these conditions.  Measuring basal serum prolactin level may be more discriminatory (low or normal in secondary hypothyroidism and increased in tertiary hypothyroidism).However, there is one exception, and that is, if the pitutary destruction is due to a prolactinoma.  One simpler test, often overlooked, is to look for the nocturnal surge of TSH which is seen in normal persons(highest TSH values occur just before a person falls asleep at night).This surge will be absent in both secondary and tertiary hypothyroidism.This may be an easier way to identify central causes of hypothyroidism.   As many of your symptoms could be caused by a hypothyroid state, you need to be investigated promptly to search for possible causes of secondary or tertialry hypothyroidism.however, i suggest that it may not be a bad idea to have your thyroid profile repeated and if shows a similar pattern, then further investigations may be initiated. Good luck!

author: Margaret24  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Mon Aug 09, 2010 7:27 pm Gender: Female
title: pituitary gland/hypothalymus
content: 1997 was diagnosed with hashimoto's (hypothyroidism).  Gained 40 pounds from symptoms.    8 years later and about 30 more pounds I had major life changes (death of a parent, pet; put into a job that wasn't trained for until the company was bought and would lose job after 20 years with same company; under-financed with owning 2 homes - selling/buying disconnect; vehicle dieing; and that's about all I can think of, but I know there was more).  By 2006, I left my job because of the stress (180/120) while on tranquilizers; didn't make it to the lay off.  I was then put on BP meds and diagnosed with anxiety; by 2007 was on cholesterol meds.  I took 17 months off to try to recover from "life" and work on losing weight and getting healthy.  By the end of 2008 and at a new job, I had lost 75 pounds with dedication to right eating and exercising.    2009 and 2010 I went through changes of eating (eating minimums of 1,200 to as much as 1,700 on high protein) and changes of exercises to jump start my weight loss because I stopped losing weight.  I actually gained about 8 pounds over 2009/2010 that won't come off, despite these changes.  Everyone that knows me is amazed that what I put in doesn't come out... i.e. for all the right proper; quality, quantity eating I do and exercising that I do not see anything on the scale.  This past January I went to a trainer for help. He put me on a high protein diet, which I follow today that keeps me away from added sugars, corn syrup and is made up of fruit, veggies, whole grains, and of course the high protein, which I enjoy after my work outs.  The exercise portion was too strenuous for me as I went through a flood in my home for a month, hurt my leg, and lost my job.  I couldn't mentally or physically keep up the pace he wanted me on (increasing incline and speed on the treadmill every week for a month).  So I decided to release myself of it and go back to my own program.  I was working out twice a day 6 days a week... still nothing... Now I'm on the 8 weeks to running a 5K... I'm up to 2.25 miles 3 days a week and then doing cross training with weight resistance the other two days.  The weekends are left for walking and housework.  Through all of this, I weigh 175 pounds.  Myself, I cannot get over that here I am this obese person jogging on a treadmill and all the other dedicated people that show up at the gym DO NOT look like me at all.  It is very upsetting; I know I have stuck with this so long and haven't been rewarded.  Although I have weight everywhere, the bulk is the big stomach I have.  This is what stops me from looking average.  I have to constantly hide it in big shirts which probably make me look bigger.  If I don't it just hangs out there.    I am so disappointed, however it has never stopped me because I don't want to gain weight, but I am at a loss on what is next for me.  I had done some reading recently because I can't get this out of my head.  I finally decide that I'm going to go to the doctor for help and my healthcare has just run out.  I'm working on getting healthcare again.  So the reading I have done is about stress/cortisol and it's role in holding weight on the body where it has thrown the hypothalymus off it's axis.  Is there any truth to this that this could screw up my metabolism.  I can honestly say that I have been doing everything right, yet I only have gotten half way home.  I want it so bad to be as healthy as I possibly can.  Can anyone shed any light for me, please?  Female: 51 years Height:  5 Foot Weight: 175 Meds:  Thyroxine .75; simavastin 40mg; lisinopril 5mg; citalopram 40mg; lorazapam when needed which I am in a spell of anxiousness this past week.

content: Hello,Apart from nutritional,metabolic, hormonal factors,and diseases one must remember genetic factors too.Without being sure what is causing the problem it is risky to shoot oneself up with hormones.Testosterone being an anabolic steroid it is no surprise that you put on weight.Also this causes salt and water retention contributing to an apparent gain of weight.Testosterone can cause hepatic damage and has been implicated in host of other conditions.Therefore it is just too risky to continue.Also the external supply would cut down production of internal hormones too.
